title: The secret history of Ronnie Scott's: 60 years of bopping and blowing off steam
text:
How did a London musician with bad gags and worse food build a mecca for jazz lovers in a "squalid" dive bar? And how is Ronnie Scott's still standing after six decades? By Martin Chilton

Ronnie Scott would regularly tell the same joke about his famous jazz club in the heart of Soho: “It’s just like home – filthy and full of strangers”.

Scott, an outstanding tenor saxophone player, died in 1996, and his now refurbished club lives on in Frith Street. The 60th anniversary of this British music institution – which started in a small basement at 39 Gerrard Street on Friday October 30 – is being celebrated this month with a gala concert at the Royal Albert Hall featuring Van Morrison, Kurt Elling,...
description: How did a London musician with bad gags and worse food build a mecca for jazz lovers in a "squalid" dive bar?
